awd_titl_txt: CRCNS Research Proposal: Collaborative Research: Mechanisms and dynamics of retronasal olfactory coding
awd_abstract_narration:
How do our brain, nose, and mouth work together to generate the flavor of food and drink?  When flavor perception goes wrong, can this play a role in diseases like obesity?  The sense of smell is very important for perceiving flavor, largely because of odors that originate in the mouth and are exhaled through the nose via the back of the throat ? a process called retronasal olfaction.  In this study, researchers from the University of Arkansas, the Virginia Commonwealth University, and Southeastern Methodist University are teamed up to gain better understanding of how retronasal olfaction works using rats as an animal model.  The researchers combine direct measurements of the brain in action together with computer simulations of air flow through the nose and neural networks. They are testing the idea that different forces in the nose caused by reversing airflow through the nasal cavity are responsible for how the brain distinguishes exhaled retronasal odors from inhaled odors. In addition, the researchers offer training opportunities at each of the three institutions and are developing an educational video game aimed at introducing users to basic concepts of neurobiology and cognitive neuroscience. 

Smells that enter the nose retronasally, i.e., from the back of the nasal cavity, play an essential role in flavor perception, yet many questions about the neuroscience of retronasal olfaction remain unanswered.  How does simply reversing the direction of air flow through the nasal cavity result in different neural input to the olfactory bulb (OB)?  How are retronasal and orthonasal (inhaled) olfactory signals encoded at the level of spiking neurons in the OB?  How do interactions within OB circuits facilitate selective response to retronasal versus orthonasal stimuli?  In this study, researchers from the University of Arkansas, the Virginia Commonwealth University, and Southeastern Methodist University are teamed up to answer these questions, guided by a two-part hypothesis. First, they hypothesize that, at the sensory periphery, retro- and orthonasal stimuli produce distinct spatiotemporal patterns of mechanosensory excitation of olfactory receptor neurons.  Second, they hypothesize that, in the OB, cell-type-specific inhibitory circuit interactions are crucial for dynamic changes in retronasal coding.  To test these hypotheses, the research team is combining high-density multi-electrode recordings in rat OB with fluid dynamics computer simulations based on the three-dimensional shape of the nasal cavity of the same animals. Moreover, the team is performing state-of-the-art realistic computational modeling to identify OB circuit-level principles of retronasal coding.  This work is expected to generate new understanding of the neural basis of retronasal olfaction that includes both peripheral mechanisms in the nose and central mechanisms at the level of M/T cells in the OB. This project is jointly funded by the cross-directorate Collaborative Research in Computational Neuroscience program, the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research(EPSCoR), and the MPS Office of Multidisciplinary Activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Flavor perception is a fundamental governing factor of eating behaviors and associated diseases such as obesity. Smells that enter the nose retronasally, i.e. from the back of the nasal cavity, play an essential role in flavor perception. Previous studies have demonstrated that orthonasal and retronasal olfaction (inhale vs. exhale) involve distinctly different brain activation, even for identical odors; these differences arise as early as the receptor neurons (ORNs) that cover the inside of our nose.

Why would our brain receive different 'smell' inputs based on the direction of the air flow? In this project we hypothesized that this difference originates from fluid mechanical forces at the periphery: ORNs respond to mechanical, as well as chemical stimuli. To investigate this, we used computational fluid dynamics to simulate and analyze shear stress patterns during natural inhalation and sniffing. We have been able to show that shear stress forces differ for orthonasal vs. retronasal air flow; i.e. inspiration vs. exhalation, in a model of the human nasal cavity. To make this quantitative, we define a phase preference map for mechanical forcing, to show which parts of the membrane receive high stress during inhale, vs exhale. Once this work is completed, the mechanical stress map can be combined with emerging research on where odorant receptors are located to give a unified view into how ORNs are stimulated.

Once mechanical stress is detected by the early stages of the sensory system, it must be transmitted to the brain to impact further processing. This project also supported research into how neural networks could perform this function. In the olfactory system, information flows from the ORNs to the olfactory bulb (OB), and then to olfactory cortex. We showed that spiking variability and co-variability (i.e. 'noise') behaves very differently in OB than olfactory cortex. In particular, the widely observed finding (in cortex) that variability and co-variability decreases at stimulus onset does not happen in OB (Ly et al. 2021). We then showed that the output cells of the OB encode ortho vs. retro direction, consistent with previous measurements from the input cells of the bulb (Craft et al. 2021). We showed that ortho vs. retro direction is transmitted from OB to olfactory cortex, and that amplification of retronasal response could be explained by synaptic adaptation acting on a more prolonged retronasal input (Craft et al. 2023). Furthermore, this model was able to explain how circuit behavior changed with pharmacological modifications, both in the direction of increased and decreased inhibition.

Finally, our study of two brain regions that are responsive to the same kind of stimuli motivated a theoretical investigation into whether this response might provide a low-dimensional, streamlined channel for information. We were able to prove that this occurs when the shared stimulus response is relatively strong compared to non-stimulus-related activity, and we demonstrated this phenomenon in action with experimental recordings from both the visual and the olfactory system (Barreiro et al., 2024).

 

Broader Impacts: This project enabled the training of 1 PhD student; altogether between three linked projects (IIS- 1912320, IIS-1912352, and IIS-1912338), two PhD students and 2 postdoctoral researchers were supported.  The PI and her collaborators gave multiple presentations to diverse audiences about the results. Trainees were also supported with travel funds to give presentations of their research at major national conferences.
